headline: 'Embrace the bald': Duo shave heads at brewery for St. Baldrick's
author: Zach Tuggle
sentences:
Event raises nearly $6K for kids with cancer
Family and friends gathered Friday night among vats of beer at The Phoenix Brewing Company to watch Ryan Nichols and Wesley Stimmel shave their heads bald.
One evening at Phoenix Brewing — he's a brewer for the company and serves as a bartender in the pub — a customer explained to him that his wavy head of hair could be a great benefit to the charity.

Close to $17,000 raised for the charity
The passion to find a cure for the disease came to Nichols in 2016 after he had let his hair grow nearly a foot, not cutting it in more than a year.
The duo combined to raise nearly $6,000 for The St. Baldrick's Foundation, a not-for-profit organization with the aim of raising funds to help find cures for children with cancer.
The event was filled with laughter, but the shaved heads of Nichols and Stimmel were a somber reminder that one in five children will not survive their cancer diagnosis.
St. Baldrick’s events have, since 2005, helped raise $314 million for lifesaving childhood cancer research, according to the organization's website, stbaldricks.org.
By the end of the night, Nichols had raised more than $5,000 and Stimmel about $500 for the charity, with more payments processed over the coming week.

More payments coming for the charity
This year's event was a little extra special because Nichols was joined by nephew, Stimmel, 12, who is from Lima.
They even coaxed a Phoenix regular, Paul Bishop, into joining in on the fun — he decided to let them shave his head to help raise awareness.
Many have come to use his hair as a calendar — the longer it is, the closer it is to spring when it's time for his St. Baldrick's shaving.

Mansfield traffic:US 30 traffic rolls on ... slowly
Once his hair was gone that first year, other patrons took notice.
As friends and family set up chairs and pulled out sets of hair clippers, the youngster retained his composure.
He realized how much awareness he could raise for the organization, so he decided to make it an annual event.
"They put forth the effort to get people to donate, and to donate themselves," Nichols said.
Piles of hair gathered on the concrete below as the pair's barbers cut away.
"I'll give you an extra $10 if you take the eyebrows," someone shouted.
"I looked it up and it seemed like a pretty good cause," Nichols said.
After six years, he's raised nearly $17,000 for the charity.
"This is the shortest I've ever had my hair," Bishop said.
That was about a year ago when his dad shaved it for him.
He already knew it will take a few months to grow back.

"I thought it was a good cause," Stimmel said.
"I really enjoy the whole process every year."
"I haven't stopped ever since," Nichols said.
The duo sat down, and the clippers came on.
"Oh my, Wesley," Nichols said with a laugh.
"I'm not really nervous," Stimmel said.
"He wanted me to join him, so I did."
"I was ready to embrace the bald."
So do his friends at the bar.
"Look at that mane of hair!"
"It actually feels good."
"I had it bald once."
